reviews.review_msg: psyc 280 was very enjoyable with dr caldbick as my prof, exams were not hard, as he made sure to outline what would be on the midterm and final by giving us a list of potential questions that would be on the test. i found lectures to be very slow but he did it to make sure we were all understanding the material

Evan is a great lecturer and I really enjoyed taking 280 with him. This is not an easy course but the material covered is constantly used in upper div courses. Evan does a great job of covering this material and making sure no one gets left behind in lectures. His exams are fair and directly related to the material.

Dr. Caldbick is hands down the best prof I've had so far. His teaching style is very engaging and he does a Q&A to check in with everyone's understanding. The grading criteria were clear, and I loved the teaching assignment! Very thankful that he gives study guides to prepare for the exam. We will miss you!

being so fr he is such a nice prof! idk my grade yet but he definetly grades fairly if you do the work. good personality! gives short answer questions ahead of time for midterm and final which is nice. only thing is wish the final was not worth 40%. SFU NEEDS TO KEEP HIM! truely a tragedy

Dr. Evan was an absolute pleasure to have as a prof, delivering the course in a very interesting manner, constantly adjusting his teaching style to benefit his students. You could genuinely see his passion for this courseâ€¦ In all honesty the BEST prof I've had in my entire career at SFU. It's so unfortunate that this is his last semester here.

Professor Caldbick is the best professor I have had at SFU and the school is making a big mistake letting him go. He is better then 90% of the professors at SFU, his lectures are amazing, he is genuinely passionate about teaching. He makes students feel very comofortable and answers any question. It's a huge loss for students at SFU to see him go.

Good prof clearly cares about students. If you put in the work, you can easily get a good grade; preparation sheets are given a week before the exam. 
This was my first semester of uni and i wasn't ready for the amount of work in such a "short" period. But I know that if I was to take it on my second or third semester I would do very well.

Lectures are timesinks. PPTs are shorthand and best understood when paired with whatever lecture he intends to give, but because he doesn't manage class time well, 3/4 of class time is just him entertaining random student questions that prevent him from getting to relevant/testable info. 

Prepare to teach yourself almost everything from textbook.

Caldbick clearly has a passion for what is being taught & it shows through lectures. Really good at making examples/easy ways to remember difficult information/topics for the exams. Overall the exams, if you studied, were straight forward. Midterm and Final were MC&SA, with the exact SA given before hand to study. I would 100% take from again!

Very nice prof and enjoyed his lectures although it is very content and memorization heavy. If this is not your main focus you will not get more than C. He marks hard I would say and the exams are not fun. You need to make a lot of time for class which I did not do but if you don't have time for it it is passable with around a C

absolute king. very intelligent and explains things in ways that are easy to understand. if biology is not your thing do not take. it's beneficial to always stay on top of your work and know what's going on in the class - if you fall behind it's hard to pick back up. overall love this guy ðŸ™Œ gorp core king and down to earth chill person

Hands down one of the best psychology profs at SFU. He is very clear when explaining some of the most difficult topics in psychology, he encourages questions and discussions to clarify topics
Two-hour core lecture,one-hour supplementary/spill-over lecture. Midterm (25%),paper outline (5%),paper introduction (10%),paper (4 pages 20%),final (40%)

Just like everybody says, he's so next level nice and smart. I never had another prof that would invite questions so much. Also, unlike most profs that would do anything to make attendance mandatory, he records all lectures. I literally had to rewatch some lectures twice cause of how hard the material is. Idk what I'd do if that wasn't an option.
Dr. Caldbick releases all the possible written questions for exams. He has clear lecture slides. Exams are very fair. Overall happy to answer questions and good lecturer!
Knows bio psych and tries to incorporate interesting info into his lectures. It's a hard course, but Evan is a great Prof

Evan was one of the best profs I've had while at SFU. He knew and loved neuroscience which made learning it so much easier. He was inspiring and had opportunities to further your knowledge outside of class. He has a clear way of teaching the content which makes it easy to understand.

Class content was heavy and involves a lot of memorizing, but he made the lectures interesting, and enjoyable. He gives you hints as to what might be on the midterm, final and also gives you the short answers to prepare too.

Course is heavy but taking it with Evan makes it bearable. Amazing guy, lenient with marking, and very smart. 3 hour lectures are a pain to attend but somehow he makes them as engaging as he can. He also encourages a lot of discussion about psychology so he's very approachable to talk to about anything.

Will outright tell you that the exams are memorization heavy but also narrow down exactly what might come up.Lectures are interesting & feel like oyu're listening to someone who remembers what being in your shoes was like. Audio recordings of the lectures are provided and were the primary reason I did better than I thought I would. Make flashcards>

Evan is clear, articulate, and engaging. As heavy as the course load is, he outlines what to expect, and how to succeed. 
On the flip-side: exams are hard. I found myself not realizing how in-depth I needed to be with absolutely every concept.

If you were ever interested in physiology and how the body works, take a class with him. He is the most knowledgeable, caring and respectful proff. The material is not easy and there is a lot of memorization, but I have never been so much interested in going to the lectures and actually doing the work.

Super kind and intelligent! Quite often, he would claim he does not know when asked questions but then would go on to give long, thoughtful answers anyway. Pretty funny and would make jokes sometimes, which certainly made the class more enjoyable. The course itself was heavy tho, so be ready to work hard.

Evan is so accommodating and helpful!! He genuinely wants you to do well and if you were considering taking one of his classes I definitely recommend it. Be ready to work for your grade though, but if you put in effort you will do well. Would 100% take a class with him as a prof again.

Evan is easily the most compassionate psyc prof I've ever had. He was dealt an unreasonably unfair hand as far as the course content went, because it was A LOT of stuff to get under our belts, yet makes it as accessible as possible to students. Take biopsyc with him if possible, because you will not get a better person for the job.

Professor Caldbick is one of the best and most caring professors I have ever had. The course is extremely dense; however, he tries his best to make it accessible and simple to everyone. He clearly cares about his students, and our mental health. I'd certainly take any other course with him!!!

he clearly cares about his students and his class and takes the time to make sure students understand his material and the content in the course. he makes long informative lectures, very engaging. genuinely one of the best profs I've had
so much love for this prof. he is amazing, very knowledgeable and I actually enjoy coming to his class. 100% recommend
Amazing & genuine person, he is the best person to take this course with, highly reccomended

Nice guy but the 3-hour lectures get boring especially since he speaks in a monotone voice. Sometimes he takes too long going over topics that aren't important. Encourages a lot of questions, which is good, but it also gets boring when people ask questions outside the course. Exams are quite tough, have to memorize some pretty trivial numbers.
Heavy long lectures but very monotone, and he doesn't have a track of time. He will go slow for the first half and rush to finish majority in the end.

very dry, heavy, 3hr lectures, not engaging at all. Will not keep track of time and rush to finish remainder of slides. Graded on 3 exams and 1 outline and a paper. Even studying for exams it is quite hard. Review questions for written entail a lot of writing. Final is cumulative even though there are 2 midterms throughout the course.
He was a great guy by the three hour lectures got super boring but material is interesting. Exams were hard

He is very monotoned, goes through lectures very slowly. There will be ~60 slides and he'll get through like 15 in the first hour then rush through the rest towards the end of lecture. LOTS of memorization required. He gives 16 written questions as practice before the exam and 4 of them are on the exam so you need to memorize  basically everything

Evan was a pretty cool dude. He posts study guides about two weeks before midterms (of which there are three) which gives you just enough time to prepare. All in all, he's pretty chill and he's easily approachable when you ask him questions.

Evan is a very down to earth and approachable professor who seems very passionate about what he teaches. This course was quite difficult as there was so much material to cover, but Evan helped with this by providing a list of short answer questions to prepare and study from for the midterms and final. Overall great professor and person!

Really personable, and great with answering questions in person or by email/canvas. This sort of class I struggle with but I really enjoyed the material, and found that it was laid out in a way that contributed to ease of understanding how different systems are connected.

If you can't attend a lecture they will be posted online, make sure to watch

I took Psyc280 online, and Evan was an awesome TA. I was skeptical about taking the course online, or taking it in general considering i havent taken bio since highschool. But Evan was extremely helpful and always explained concepts clearly.

Amazing professor! I took 280 with him and have since been taking every other course he teaches. I took 280 online but he still took the time to call me on the phone and provide feedback about a paper.

This was the first online class that I took at SFU and I'm very thankful Evan was the instructor! He had very useful discussions each week and was also willing to meet in person to go over midterm results. We were very well prepared for our exams, which is important because there is a ton of content for this class!

Took this course online but Evan was super helpful with weekly check ins and exam prep. There was a lot of material covered, but he advised us on what to focus on which helped a lot. Super helpful when concepts were hard to understand and very accessible.

Excellent Professor, Evan is very clear about the material and you will know what to expect on the midterms and finals. Although the course is a lot of work, Evan made himself available after hours and explains things very clearly.
good teacher
great big chilli peppers!

The last writer is the lame narco who created problems for all of us with the grading. This semester's distance ed course  was a ton of work. For Dr. Brown's part, he corrected our assignments and midterms in one day in all cases. He answered all questions in WebCT. I have no complaints about this course. The last writer is just a complainer.

Don't take his distance ed course for BioPsych. His instructions for the final exam: "study all 10 chapters in depth". It was a nightmare, he was snappy to the students online and did absolutely nothing to make the course manageable.

Bryan's an awesome prof - super interested in what he's talking about. Is about the only prof able to keep his class engaged for a full three hour lecture. Only a midterm and a final, and they're pretty tough. And he's definitely more attractive than your average prof...helps keep you interested if you're into it

nice teacher,the class was really easy. i didnt read most of the chapters and didnt study for the exam and still got a good grade. if you dont know a answer on an exam just read the next question and it will give you the answer.

Neil was nice and passionate when teaching. The concepts are definitely a jump tho! Don't be fooled by the others because this indeed is a full on NEUROSCI class. Midterm avg was 67%: difficulty wasn't too bad but there was just so much to remember. Get ready to read A LOT lol and best of luck to the non science savvys (me)

yeah don't listen to the others saying this class is easy. One of the hardest 200 level courses I've taken. This class is straight neuroscience and nothing psych related. Lots of reading/difficult concepts. Take other classes if you're looking to boost gpa/if there are other options. Unless you like neurosciences, DONT TAKE THIS CLASS.

Loved Watson! I took this intersession so the midterm was 35% and the final was 55%. The material is very intimidating but really interesting and he explains everything super well. Just read the text and go to lectures. Exams are easy, study the material and memorize. It's multiple choice and the short answers are light work. He's a sweetie.

Neil is an amazing professor, super knowledgeable guy. The textbook explains everything honestly, I took this class intersession so it was pretty intense but if you keep up with the readings it lays things out super clear. Hes really funny and makes the sometimes dry material, interesting. Exams are straightforward he does not try and trick you.

Took this class online, was entirely taught by TA who was very helpful. However, if you don't need to take this course as a pre-req I'd highly recommend against taking it. The entire course depends how well you're able to memorize concepts from the textbook. The class average for the midterm and final were both around 64%

This course is what made me want to change my major to behavioural neuroscience. I ended up loving it so much, but it was super textbook heavy. The tutor-marker Lindsey Bochon was super sweet and helpful. Sometimes you had to read 100+ pages a week for the quizzes due Sundays. I took this online.

Very knowledgeable and funny guy. Sometimes talks really fast and assumes you know what he's talking about. The learning curve is so incredibly steep for the average psychology student. It's straight up biology and neuroscience and there is no "psychology" content. You have to study super hard for the quizzes and exams.

I took this as a DisEd course and only gave a 1/5 because the TA taught the whole course. Read the textbook because the 15 min summary lectures are useless. Paper was super easy. Make sure to memorize the textbook because that's the only way to do well on the weekly quizzes and exams. If possible, I would recommend taking this course in person.

Would strongly recommend getting in touch with the TAs for help with the material as Neil doesn't really teach anything for this course. 2 exams, 1 paper, weekly quizzes were pretty straightforward. His lectures are useless as it just regurgitates info from the textbook so if you want to do well, read and memorize the text.

The lectures were 2.5 - 3 hours long, and were really dense with a lot of information. It helps to pre-read the textbook chapter before the lecture. Class was hard b/c of the vast amount of info to learn, but Neil is a great lecturer and made the material really interesting to learn. Exams were straight forward, as long as you attend + read!

The biggest reason why I have such a high difficulty selection was because I felt so overwhelmed with the readings. There was a lot but I found the lectures not too bad despite being long. That was the only time I enjoyed some of the material. Also, the time limit of 15 mins for 30MC quizzes was another thing I dont miss and never will.

Dr. Watson is an incredibly caring professor. When I reached out to him outside of class, he was very understanding and accommodating. Lindsay was a fantastic TA and really really helpful because she breaks down the dense material. Course itself was difficult, lots of reading and memorization. I took the online version of the course.

Took 280 in fall 2020 and it was a 99% self-taught course which is unacceptable given it was the same tuition cost. A 10-15 minute weekly powerpoint presentation was made available but it just regurgitated textbook material without expanding on it. Reading other reviews I feel like I really missed out on what could be a good prof in person.

Amazing and engaging prof. If you are a Neuroscience Major and have already taken BPK 205 this class is not that hard. Make up practice written questions to study for the exams. Practice typing, because it's all online. Lectures will feel long, but the exams are straightforward with no tricks. Took as an intersession class and it was 100% doable.

We have a 2.5h pre-recorded lectures two a week, from a past semester. They get posted on 11:30am on Tuesdays and thursdays (partial notes the day before) and have a quiz due by 12:59pm Friday. His schedule doesn't let us use the weekend for much, only a single project have 6 weeks to day, which that took me 5 hours. Education quality is good.

Dr Watson is a very knowledgeable and entertaining prof. The material is dry but he uses anecdotes to keep it interesting. Most of the marks come from the exams (no quizzes) and they are conceptual based so you need to understand the material to do well.

Dr. Watson is one of the best professors I 've had at SFU. He really cares about his students and is willing to talk to you after class. He is also a really good teacher. I would definitely take any class he has to offer. His courses are a lot of memorization so be prepared for that.

Neil is very passionate and knowledgeable about biopsyc. His lectures are 3 hours so it can be tough to sit through but he does his best to make it interesting with personal anecdotes and funny stories. Midterm and final were fair but you do need to memorize quite a bit. Paper was a grade booster. He wrote the textbook so lectures overlap well

Super difficult course that requires a lot of memorization, hes a decent prof who is nice. lectures were really dry and a bit boring but if u have questions in the middle of lecture he will asnwer them. he uses slides that are lenghty and mostly reads off them. project is super easy

Hes a great prof. He seems very passionate about biopsyc. I would definitely take a class with him in the future. The easiest way to do well on this course is to memorize his lecture notes. Most of the exam is based off of those.
One of the best profs I've had at SFU. Engaging lectures and fair exams

Lovely, and obviously very well versed in his topic. Difficult class but hold on for dear life and focus on knowledge over grades, and you'll be alright! Very funny, approachable, respectful to students, and seems to genuinely love talking about biopsyc. Def take with him.

PSYC280 He wrote his own textbook which is very comprehensive. His lectures are very long, but he is quite funny, slightly awkward as he tries to be "relatable". His exams are quite hard, especially the written part. DO NOT SKIP THE LECTURE.

He is funny when he lectures, and they are recorded so you don't need to go to class, but he draws on his provided lecture slides so if you want those you'll have to go. Lecturers are 3 hours.. that was tough to sit in. Midterm and final were hard, but there is a project that is super easy. I failed both and got 90% on the project and passed.

Lectures are long and fairly dry but Dr. Watson is friendly and more than happy to answer questions during class. His slides are sometimes confusing to decipher but the textbook and lecture recordings help. The midterm and final are fair, as long as you study the slides AND textbook.  The project is a super easy 20%.  A bio background helps.

Material can be super dry and dense. Having a bio background definitely helps, but can be understood if you study hard. He records his lectures so participation isn't mandatory if you take it in person. Sometimes he likes to include extra bits of info you wouldn't find in the textbook and will put it on the MT and final so beware of that.

Dr. Watson is a good prof. Explains complicated concepts well, and makes any dry content relatively interesting. Lectures can drag on and be long sometimes though. EXAMS ARE TOUGH, so don't slack off, and make sure you do the readings and study! The project/paper is an easy grade booster though so try to do it well.  Interesting, but not easy.

Fairly difficult course, but an A is attainable as long as you do the readings and study for exams. I didn't attend many lectures, because all lecture slides and lecture recordings were posted online.

If you ever get the chance to take a course with this not only amazing professor, but amazing human being, DON'T MISS THE OPPORTUNITY. I messed up big time while taking this course, and he not only gave me a second chance, but told me to pay this kindness forward. His lectures are entertaining, informative, and he truly cares about his students.
A true asset at this dump that is SFU. The best prof I had there. Nice, accessible, funny, intelligent. Thank you, Mr. Watson.
Best. Prof. Ever. Jump at any chance you get to take a class with him.

Best prof I've ever had! Extremely well rounded in terms of consistency within the course and overall clarity with subject material. Material is dense and you'll need to put your time into it, but exams and grading are fair to reflect your work (TA makes a difference- visit office hours for marking specifics as they can be scrupulous!)
A great prof with passion for the subject, and the course touches on some really interesting topics but is very heavy. Exams aren't easy, but are fair.
Great lectures, always interesting and high-energy! Tests and papers were fair if you put effort in.

Best prof in the world. Super intelligent, crystal clear, very fun lectures. Great personality and very friendly to approach. Extremely helpful to those who ask. If you are interested or want to learn about biological psychology, Neil is the man!

Amazing prof! Materials covered in this course were never my strong point but he was extremely clear with his lectures. Highly entertaining to listen to and very willing to help. Textbook is really great but studying lecture notes will suffice for getting through exams. Hard material and requires review. I definitely recommend this prof!!!

Great prof!!! Knows exactly what he is teaching and extremely helpful to students who approached to him. Although the material was extremely hard, Watson made it very clear and fun for us and tons of information are presented to us in each lecture. Exams are hard but fair. Lots of memorizing, so study hard and you'll do fine!
BEST Prof EVER!!!!!!!!
HE IS THE BEST PROFESSOR IN THE WORLDDDDDDDDD OMG I LOVE HIM SO MUCH! IF YOU ARE SFU STUDENT. YOU ARE IN LUCK TO HAVE HIM AS YOUR PROF :) TAKE HIS CLASS WHEN YOU CAN :D/!
he is so funny! actually made the three hour lecture enjoyable for the most part. its nice when you can tell when you have a prof who is really interested in what they are teaching.
Great teacher..difficult material. Class average for midterm was 58%-He said he may not scale since class average is always low in 280. Don't miss a class and memorize memorize memorize!

Not an easy class, at all. So much information, so much memorization. But, Neil Watson makes this class so much better! His lectures are pretty interesting, and he makes it much easier to understand, especially for someone like me who's strong point has never been bio. Midterm and final make up 90% of the mark, so lots of studying required!
I loved this class, and you how sometimes a professor can squash your love of a subject like so many ants beneath his heel?  This was anything but.  So many hearts.
Had bio psych and endocrinology with him. Good prof, but the courses are challenging.

Dr. Watson was fantastic. Very engaging lecturer, keeps some difficult material entertaining. He obviously loves his area of research and it makes him great to listen to and learn from. Also very good about posting notes and recordings.

The material itself is hard, but the prof is nice. He tries to explain the concepts clearly so u wont be confused. He talks quite fast, so listen to the recordings if you don't get what he said. I am sure that many people will show up when it comes to the sex chapter. Midterm and final are hard, but he is a fair marker. 45% midterm and 55% final!

awesome prof, awesome material! its pretty hard so be sure you are really interested! i don't think i did well overall (have not received the grade as of yet) but it was totally worth it, it was really interesting stuff!

i really enjoyed taking bio psych with him! very engaging and makes the material much more interesting than it really is. the final is hard, but just go to lecture and study his ppt slides and you will do fine
Amazing.  Exams are hard, but fair.  Tends to focus on the "then what" parts of the material.  Definitely will seek Neil out for 381.

Awesome lecturer! Very funny & intelligent. Never missed class, esp. sex lec! MC really hard, SA easy. Need to listen to entire lec. & memorize EVERYTHING! Didn't even read book. He talks really fast... so listen to taped lectures!
nice guy but tough

This guy is a disaster.  He didn't even know how to put lecture notes online.  He scan all his written overheads to the powerpoint which makes them all horizontal (hard to print).  Eventually you waste at least half an hour printing materials each week!

nice guy!! very knowledgeble and funny!! like his little stories of life event ..(e.g., bunny the garage dog) but its not a easy class average is 40~50 percent for midterm. I agree with the guy before Brian is not some one you can trust, he pretend to be good with you but gives you extrem low marks.
No Comments

I slept through all of his classes; his lecture slides are useless and everything he tests on is from the textbook. There's a lot of info to remember so if you like cramming, this is the course for you! Don't cram for the exams the day right before like I did...

He's a nice prof but the class is very hard to sit through (3 hrs btw). The lecture slides provided are also not really helpful for the exams, so just read to textbook and you'll do fine. Lots of information and material to remember, basically the whole textbook. This class is more of a BIO class rather than PSYC

He's a good prof but the lectures are very hard to sit through no matter how hard you try. That being said, Quiz 1, MT 1 and Quiz 2 mainly have 90% questions from the study questions on the textbook website (USE THEM!!). Study lectures for the final! Anyone that has taken any BPK or BIO courses will find this course easy. Tests aren't cumulative.

Oh man... not a good prof. He knows about sleep (his area), but he "can't exactly remember" a lot of other things. If you are a science student and have taken any bpk courses of the nervous system you will get an A (the material is super basic and easy). He said a few incorrect things in class as well. Try to take it with someone else.

Skip class? Won't affect you AT ALL! He is very monotone, like the other reviews say, and tests entirely from the textbook! The 3 hour lectures are very boring and basically summaries of the textbook in a more boring way. Use the online component of the textbook and you'll be fine! A lot to memorize but quizzes and tests are not cumulative!! :D

Ralph knows a lot about the subject but talks in monotone the ENTIRE time! Easily the hardest lecture I've ever had to sit through.  The lectures are pointless too because he only tests on the textbook information.  Make sure you read every word in the chapter readings because he tests on the smallest details.

This class was basically memorizing the text or else you wont do well.  His lectures were long and boring, with the exception on circadian rhythms which is his area of expertise.  I managed an A but worked for it.

Ralph is a very informative guy! But it does get very difficult to sit in his class for 3 hours long. Read the textbook carefully as he tests on details. You can also read his lecture notes and probably the lecture as well. Overall he's an alright professor.

He was very boring. It was hard to pay attention past the first 15 minutes. He is very knowledgable about the subject but drones on in monotone and his slides are hardly informative. However, if you read the textbook WELL you'll be okay.
Hard to survive a 3hr lecture with his monotone voice. Lecture slides aren't really helpful either. Memorize the textbook, use the slides as a supplement and you will be fine.

This prof is quite inconsistent. While he obviously knows the topic in depth, there is a lack of ability to transfer that knowledge in his lecture. Honestly, he tends to attempt to level the information in a modern way, but completely fails at it. Isn't the most responsive or supportive when you email him too. Good luck

very monotone and hard to keep concentrated because he uses difficult words to process. however very interested in his field, funny stories/jokes but even then you'll find yourself zoning in and out. exams are fair but hard to study for since there is so much to know

this is a great class with really interesting materials. However it is all biology with no real mention to pyschology so only take it if you are interested in science to some extent. He is so boring and the textbook teaches way better than he does!

his lectures were so boring that i fell asleep all the time. the midterm & final were mostly multiple choice with some short answer questions. they were hard unless you knew all the material from the text & his lectures.
He is kinda boring, but t he course was awesome! SOoo good
So boring even he has trouble staying awake.  He's more bored than you are.
using the study guide helps a LOT.
Lectures are boring and long but the text is interesting to read.  Exams are ok.
Very interesting course, fairly easy if you do the readings
lectures are dry, course is easy if you find it interesting
Always Helpful. Explains things well

I cannot believe this man gets paid to "teach" this course. No teaching occurred that I could detect. Posted no more than 10X total on WebCT discussion, the last time was the 5th of October. Didn't even reply to one email I sent - Wow!

Hard class if you are not good at memorizing. Txtbook is extremely hard to read & comprehend, containing massive amount of info which is quite the disaster since its distant ed. MT class average was 58%. However, I did all the study questions online and it helped me get the highest mark in class.. 93% on the midterm and an A+ on my final grade :)

What a mistake to take this class by distance! The text is poorly written and highly specific, and the exams are even worse. Written questions on exams are very specific about random things (e.g. two questions on hyena hermaphrodism, which was discussed in a small box largely unrelated to the rest of the text). Terrible! GPA killer!

Crazy online course!! you have to memorize EVERYTHING in the text in order to get a decent mark in the exams. assignments are impossible to get perfect because for some reason 20% of the questions are out from the 5th edition of the text(currently using 6th edition)and you can't find those answer unless u search in the 5th addition.

This course was quite challenging. The first exam (in my opinion) went into far too much detail. It improved some for the final, although there were some questions out of left field. In the end, though, he is an approachable and knowledgeable prof.

Honestly the worst prof/class I have ever had in my life. Seriously made me hate psyc. He does not know what the hell he is doing when he is trying to teach. Put it this way: the class average for the exams were around 50%. something is wrong there. 3 hours every week for 3 months and still didn't learn a thing from this guy!!

I think he might be an ok prof after he gets some more experience, but right now avoid his classes! The material was hard enough to learn, but he doesn't do much to make it any easier. I agree that he does kind of talk down to students. If you take a class with him just memorize the text and hope you can understand his confusing drawings.

Prof doesn't seem to really know what he's talking about. Lecture is ok, when he uses slides, but when he tries to write on the overheads all he does is draw confusing diagrams. Is open to helping students, but speaks down to you in a condescending way. Pay attention to the text than lec. most of the lecture he just glosses over whats in the text.
Try hard... jokes fall flat
